Graphical abstract Co-dimers of the vinylidene compound isobutene with different 1-alkenes as well as homo-dimers from other vinylidene compounds are generated in high selectivities using (4-cyclooctene-1-yl)(1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-acetylacetonato)nickel as a catalyst. Regarding co-dimerization reactions very high selectivies for head-to-head couplings of up to 99% are achieved. Beside co-dimers as main products, homo-dimers of both substrates are obtained as relevant by-products. By careful variation of the initial proportion of substrates the distribution of co-dimers and homo-dimers can effectively be adjusted. Depending on shifts in product selectivity a deeper insight into the insertion mechanism is concluded. Although head-to-head couplings of other vinylidene compounds are also feasible with very high selectivities of >99%, different limitations for the catalytic system are shown. Subsequent considerations result in an extension of catalyst lifetime applying additives with internal electron-poor double bonds. InChIKeys VFZIUYUUQFYZBR-UHFFFAOYSA-N LCGKSWCYAYDYHT-BQYQJAHWSA-N IIFTWLCWSCZAKE-SOFGYWHQSA-N GHBKCPRDHLITSE-SNAWJCMRSA-N Keywords Co-dimerization Nickel Head-to-head linkage Homogeneous catalysis Catalyst stabilization 1 Introduction The dimerization of alkenes by transition metal complexes is of considerable industrial interest [1]. Although several catalysts are known to generate dimers from 1-alkenes, only a few catalysts are capable of producing head-to-head dimers in high selectivities [2–7]. In most cases, alkenes such as propene and 1-butene are dimerized on large scale to give mainly head-to-tail or tail-to-tail products which are used, e.g., as feedstocks for gasoline blending or alcohol production [8,9]. To obtain 1-alkene dimers for advanced applications a control of product selectivity is crucial. Following the pathways of insertion various isomers are possible (Scheme 1 ). In contrast to linear aliphatic 1-alkenes, similar vinylidene compounds usually show no reactivity for a head-to-head linkage. Due to the twofold alkyl substitution in beta position, the double-bond of aliphatic vinylidene compounds possesses a higher electron density and shows stronger polarization compared to linear aliphatic 1-alkenes. In consequence, the reactivity of vinylidene compounds strongly depends on the ready formation of a carbocation by either Lewis or Brønsted-acids. Considering isobutene, the simplest representative of aliphatic vinylidene compounds, many transformations such as the conversion to methyl tert-butyl ether, isooctene, polyisobutene and butyl rubber have been industrially established [10]. Owing to the reaction pathway, the resulting products are always highly branched. However, we very recently showed a novel approach towards head-to-head homo-dimers from isobutene using (4-cyclooctene-1-yl)(1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-acetylacetonato)nickel 1 as well as analogous aluminum activated nickel catalysts [11]. The one component catalyst 1 was investigated in detail for oligomerization reactions with different 1-alkenes before but reactions of vinylidene compounds were not covered [12–21]. In this work, the nickel catalyzed head-to-head coupling is widened to co-dimerization experiments with isobutene as well as homo-dimerization reactions with other vinylidene substrates. Investigations on co-dimerization have led to an improved understanding regarding the ways of insertion. Additionally, substrate limitations of the catalyst as well as a novel approach for catalyst stabilization have been found. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents All preparations and manipulations were performed under a dry, oxygen-free argon atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. Argon gas (99.998%, AIR LIQUIDE, Düsseldorf, Germany) was passed through a P2O5 column and an OXISORB® cartridge (Messer, Bad Soden, Germany). Chemicals were purchased from Acros Organics (Geel, Belgium) and Sigma Aldrich (Steinheim, Germany) and dried over 4Å molecular sieves. Isobutene, received from EVONIK (Marl, Germany), as well as propene, obtained from Messer (Bad Soden, Germany), were used without further purification. Catalyst (4-cyclooctene-1-yl)(1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-acetylacetonato)nickel (1) was synthesized as described and stored as a m-xylene solution at −20°C [11]. 2.2 Oligomerization experiments All reactions were performed in a 25mL custom-made stainless steel autoclave [22]. In a typical experiment under inert conditions, complex 1 was transferred to the reactor as a m-xylene solution. Solvent was removed in vacuum (10−3 mbar); additives and alkenes were added sequentially as required. Gaseous alkenes (isobutene, propene) were added volumetrically as a liquid with a pressure resistant tube. The autoclave was placed in a preheated oil bath at the desired temperature. The magnetic stirrer was accelerated to 500rpm. After 2h, the reaction was stopped by rapidly cooling to room temperature using an ice bath. The conversion of isobutene was determined by analyzing the gas phase using a mixture of the internal standard isobutane and the substrate isobutene (20/80wt%). A sample was taken from the autoclave by shortly opening the valve connected to a gas tight sample bag (SKC, Valley View Road, USA) equipped with a septum. The collected gas-sample was injected manually to the gas chromatograph by a gas syringe. The conversions were determined comparing the area of the inert standard isobutane and the remaining isobutene. After degassing, a sample of the liquid phase was taken and analyzed by gas chromatography with n-dodecane as internal standard. 2.3 Product analysis Routine gas chromatographic analyses were performed on a HP 6890 instrument (Hewlett-Packard GmbH, Waldbronn, Germany) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a HP5 capillary column (30m, diameter 0.25mm, film thickness 0.25μm) connected to an auto sampler. GC-MS analyses of the hydrogenated products were carried out on a Hewlett-Packard 5973 (70eV). Hydrogenation was achieved using 10% Pd/C catalyst applying 20atm of hydrogen. Total conversion to alkanes was accomplished after 16h at 80°C using 10mg Pd/C and 2mL of the alkene mixture. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Co-dimerization of isobutene with different 1-alkenes Due to the high selectivity of catalyst 1 for the insertion sequence 1,2 in the first step and 2,1 in the second step, linearly linked products are observed as main products using aliphatic 1-alkenes. A catalytic cycle for the generation of head-to-head dimers from isobutene is given in Scheme 2 . In co-dimerization reactions of isobutene with different 1-alkenes, beside co-dimers, homo-dimers of both substrates were expected as relevant by-products, since 1 is active in homo-dimerization reactions of each substrate. Scheme 3 shows a schematic summary of the structural isomers that were expected as products. Beside linearly linked head-to-head products, the formation of branched dimers as well as higher oligomers must be taken into consideration, since linearity and dimer selectivity for most alkenes are significantly lower than for isobutene (Table 1 ). In the homo-dimerization of ethene, 1-butene is formed rapidly. Since 1-butene is highly reactive itself, higher oligomers were formed from further additions of ethene to 1-butene resulting in 1-hexene formation. Additionally, formed 1-alkenes are able to react with one another to create higher alkenes. Consequently, dimer selectivity is very low when ethene is applied. Using propene, dimer selectivity is also low, due to the formation of 1-hexene during the reaction. In comparison to reactions of ethene higher propene dimer selectivity can be easily explained since 2-hexene is the main product of the dimerization reaction. In general, alkenes containing internal double-bonds are less reactive. For example, the simplest internal aliphatic alkene 2-butene reacts 20 times slower than 1-butene. The considerable formation of linear dimers in the reaction of 2-butene is a result of the isomerization activity of the catalyst (Scheme 4 ). Isomerization occurs when insertion of alkene is followed by an H abstraction from the adjacent carbon atom instead of insertion of an additional alkene. In the homo-dimerization of 1-butene and 1-hexene the linear main products inevitably possess an internal double bond. As already described for dimer formation with 2-butene, minor amounts of trimers from 1-butene and 1-hexene are a result of an in situ isomerization of the double-bond to the terminal position of the dimer followed by a further oligomerization step. Additionally, a direct trimer formation is conceivable if a branched linked dimer with a vinylidene functionalization, formed by a 1,2 insertion in the second step, reacts with a further substrate molecule. Unlike many other oligomerization catalysts, trimers are not formed from chain propagation since the β-H-elimination rate of 1 is considerably higher than the alkene insertion rate. Using neohexene (3,3-dimethyl-1-butene) and isobutene excellent dimer selectivities as well as linearities are achieved. The outstanding dimer selectivity in the case of neohexene can be explained by the dimer structure. Caused by the tert-butyl groups an isomerization of the double bond to a terminal position is impossible. In the course of our investigations regarding the linear linkage of isobutene co-dimerization reactions of isobutene with different alkenes were investigated in detail. Propene, 1-hexene and neohexene were selected as comonomers in order to observe effects caused by the substrate structures on both dimer distribution as well as linearity of the products. Due to the higher activity of the used alkenes in comparison to isobutene corresponding homo-dimers were expected as main products. Results of co-dimerization experiments are shown in Table 2 . In all experiments the desired head-to-head products were obtained with remarkable selectivities. Beside high proportions of linearly linked co-dimers, homo-dimers of isobutene as well as homo-dimers of the comonomer were obtained. Applying propene the results suffered from a low overall dimer selectivity (Sdimers,overall =37%) (Table 2, Entry 1). Due to the stepwise characteristic of the mechanism 1-hexene which is formed during the homo-dimerization of propene, itself is reactive and led to further products. As a result, linearity of the propene homo-dimers observed in the reaction mixture decreased at high conversions, since 1-hexene reacts preferentially in comparison to branched homo-dimers of propene. In order to increase the overall dimer selectivity catalyst concentration and reaction time were reduced (Entry 2). As intended, a higher overall dimer selectivity was obtained (Sdimers,overall =80%). Again high proportion of co-dimers was found (SIB+AL =51%). This time, isobutene homo-dimers were only found to a minor extent (SIB+IB =4%), whereas propene homo-dimers as well as co-dimers were obtained in a higher proportion (SAL+AL =45%). Linearity of the propene homo-dimers was enhanced to (l:b=78:22) which proofed the described preference of 1-hexene for subsequent oligomerization at longer reaction times. Linearity of the observed co-dimers was even higher (l:b=88:12) and homo-dimers of isobutene were almost exclusively head-to-head linked (l:b=99:1). In contrast to the co-dimerization reaction of isobutene with propene, the co-dimerization of isobutene with 1-hexene directly resulted in a high overall dimer selectivity of 91% (see Entry 3). As already noticed in the co-dimerization with propene, the selectivity for head-to-head coupling increased with the installation of isobutene. The homo-dimerization of 1-hexene led to C12-alkenes with a linearity of 70% (l:b=70:30). Head-to-head co-dimers of isobutene and 1-hexene were formed with l:b ratio of 84:16 and head-to-head homo-dimers of isobutene were formed with l:b ratio of 99:1. This trend in selectivity demonstrates that the high selectivity for the insertion of isobutene is maintained in the co-dimerization reaction. Highest overall dimer proportions and head-to-head selectivities were achieved using neohexene as the co-substrate. The slightly lower overall dimer selectivity in the co-dimerization in comparison to the homo-dimerization of neohexene (see Table 1) is due to the fact that co-dimers with isobutene, like isobutene homo-dimers, can possess an active terminal double bond. Further investigations were conducted to study effects of the substrate ratio on the product formation. Due to the high dimer selectivity as well as the very high linearity of all products the co-dimerization of isobutene and neohexene was chosen as a model reaction. In contrast to the co-dimerization experiment with equimolar amounts of substrates (corresponds to an isobutene mass fraction of 40%), an even higher selectivity towards co-dimers was obtained applying higher isobutene ratios (Fig. 1 ). Highest selectivity for the formation of co-dimers was achieved with an initial molar fraction of 80% isobutene (corresponds to an isobutene mass fraction of 73%). In this case, 65% co-dimers, 20% neohexene homo-dimers and 15% isobutene (mass fractions) homo-dimers were formed. At low proportions of isobutene, the formation of neohexene homo-dimers is plainly preferred. In order to analyze the observed trends in product formation further, a schematic summary of the assumed insertion routes is given in Scheme 5 . Conversions of isobutene (IB) and neohexene (NH) together with the selectivities towards the three product fractions diisobutene (DIB), neohexene-isobutene codimer (CODI) and neohexene-dimer (DNH) were determined from a series of experiments with variation of the initial isobutene/neohexene ratio. Resulting data enabled us to make a rough estimation of either the relative occupation of the catalytic species by the monomers and products as well as the relative reactivity of these nickel-alkyls with the free monomers in solution. The necessary assumption to do this is that during reaction the respective nickel-alkyl species are in equilibrium (instantaneous equilibration), which seems reasonable since the first alkene insertion into the nickel-hydride is proven to be fast and reversible [19]. It must be taken into account that product alkenes are also able to undergo an equilibrium insertion into the nickel hydride. Chemical activity of the nickel catalyst, which cannot be measured directly, is set at unity for simplicity. We included the following equilibria (Ni here means a nickel hydride species able to insert an alkene to form a nickel alkyle): (1) Ni + IB = Ni _ IB (2) Ni + NH = Ni _ NH (3) Ni + DIB = Ni _ DIB (4a) Ni + Codi 1 = Ni _ Codi1 (4b) Ni + Codi 2 = Ni _ Codi2 (5) Ni + DNH = Ni _ DNH The equilibrium constants are given as (6) K ( Ni _ IB ) = [ Ni _ IB ] [ Ni ] * [ IB ] (7) K ( Ni _ NH ) = [ Ni _ NH ] [ Ni ] * [ NH ] (8) K ( Ni _ DIB ) = [ Ni _ DIB ] [ Ni ] * [ DIB ] (9) K ( Ni _ Codi ) = [ Ni _ Codi ] [ Ni ] * [ Codi ] (10) K ( Ni _ DNH ) = [ Ni _ DNH ] [ Ni ] * [ DNH ] Since the concentrations of the both Codimer fractions (Codi1 and Codi2) were determined experimentally only as sum of both, the equilibrium constants for the formation of a nickel-codimer-alkyl were set to be equal. The species formulated this way are assumed to react in the following way: (A) Ni_IB+IB=Ni_DIB (B) Ni_IB+NH=Ni_Codi1 (C) Ni_NH+NH=Ni_DNH (D) Ni_NH+IB=Ni_Codi2 This gives the following rate equations: (11) r ( A ) = k ( A ) * [ Ni _ IB ] * [ IB ] (12) r ( B ) = k ( B ) * [ Ni _ IB ] * [ NH ] (13) r ( C ) = k ( C ) * [ Ni _ NH ] * [ NH ] (14) r ( D ) = k ( D ) * [ Ni _ NH ] * [ IB ] In the calculations, the concentrations are taken as mass fraction (so that the equilibrium constants are dimensionless) and time as hour. Since the ratio of catalyst mass versus total mass was not constant in the real experiments, the reaction times were normalized. For simplicity, the consecutive reaction of dimers toward trimers and higher oligomers is assumed not to take place, which seems to be adequate looking at the very low concentrations of consecutive products in all experiments. A least square fit delivered the numerical values for the kinetic parameters given in Table 3 . The experimental results are shown in comparison with those of the simulation in Figs. 1 and 2 . The following conclusions can be drawn (1) From all alkenes regarded, diisobutene is the molecule with the lowest affinity to the active nickel species. (2) Isobutene is adsorbed to the active nickel species essentially stronger than neohexene. (3) The codimers and di-neohexene show a high affinity to the active nickel species resulting in an inhibition of the catalyst. (4) In the second insertion step a reaction of neohexene is strongly preferred. Calculated transients of alkene mass fractions and nickel alkyl proportions are given in Fig. 3 . It is shown that the active nickel centers are almost completely occupied by codimers and neohexene dimers during the reaction; only a small proportion of the active catalyst (∼10%) remains for dimerization reactions. 3.2 Homo-dimerization of vinylidene compounds The promising results in homo-dimerization and co-dimerization of isobutene encouraged us to investigate reactions with other vinylidene compounds. To get a deeper insight on substrate influences on activity as well as selectivity vinylidene compounds from different olefinic classes including α-ω-diene as well as aromatic and aliphatic compounds were chosen (Table 4 ). Applying the α,ω-diene 2-methyl-1,5-hexadiene products were only detected in traces in the reaction mixture (Table 4, Entry 1). The isolated double bonds seem to cause a chelat blocking of the catalyst. A similar type of chelate blocking was already observed by adding cyclooctadiene in the dimerization of 1-butene. In this case, addition of an equimolar amount of cyclooctadiene to 1 results in an 8-fold lower dimerization activity [15]. Using 2,3-dimethyl-1-butene, head-to-head products were generated exclusively (l:b>99:1) (Entry 2). In addition, a high tendency for isomerization to 2,3-dimethyl-2-butene was found (S isomer =90%). The outstanding linearity in the linkage, in comparison to the reactions with isobutene, can be explained by the nickel alkyl complex that is formed from a 2,1 insertion in the first step. Instead of undergoing an insertion that leads to head-to-tail dimers, the nickel alkyl bond is more likely to undergo beta hydride elimination leading towards almost inactive thermodynamic favored 2,3-dimethyl-2-butene. 2,4,4-Trimethyl-1-pentene is also tolerated by the catalyst. Dimers were formed with yields of 5%. Isomerization did only occur in a lower proportion since the isomer 2,4,4-trimethyl-2-pentene is thermodynamically less favored. Finally, the aromatic compounds α-methylstyrene and 1,1-diphenylethene were tested. Although similar to isobutene these substrates are sterically highly demanding, they differ significantly from aliphatic vinylidene compounds in electronic properties. The terminal double bond possesses a much lower electron density than that of isobutene. As a result, 1,1-diphenylethene did not show any activity in the dimerization reaction (Entry 5). Applying α-methylstyrene, small amounts of dimers and trimers were found. Surprisingly, in contrast to all other reactions, applying aromatic vinylidene compounds, a formation of metallic nickel precipitate did not occur. This result encouraged us to investigate a novel way for catalyst stabilization. 3.3 Stabilization of 1 As already described, the fast deactivation of 1 is the main hindrance for an industrial implementation of the catalyst [11]. In the first step of deactivation 1 undergoes a reductive elimination resulting in the formation of metallic nickel as black precipitate, hexafluoroacetylacetone and cyclooctadiene. In a second step of deactivation hexafluoroacetylacetone reacts via metallation to form inactive Ni(hfacac)2 and cyclooctene (Scheme 6 ). In order to prevent the decomposition of the catalyst we focused on the back reaction to the active complex starting from the components formed by the first deactivation step. This approach seems promising since 1 is synthesized by an oxidative addition of hexafluoroacetylacetone to bis(cyclooctadiene)nickel(0) (Scheme 7 ). The formation of nickel(0) during the reaction leads to the formation of nickel conglomerates which are easily noticeable as a black precipitate. Presumably the fast conglomeration of atomic nickel is the major reason for the fast deactivation process. To prevent a nickel conglomeration and to allow the back formation to the active catalyst a coordinative stabilization of nickel(0) by additional alkenes seems reasonable. A well-known way for nickel(0) stabilization is the use of cyclooctadiene. However, the use of cyclooctadiene or other diene compounds leads to a chelating blocking of the active catalyst. For a coordination of nickel(0) electron poor alkenes are most appropriate. For example, the electron poor double bond of maleic anhydride binds roughly 106 times more strongly to (bipyridine)Ni(0) than does the electron rich double bond of vinyl acetate (Scheme 8 ) [23,24]. Since 1 does not tolerate the presence of functionalized alkenes, we tested the aromatic substituted internal alkenes trans-stilbene, cis-stilbene and tetraphenylethene. Due to the aromatic substitution the internal π-bonds possess low electron density. Additionally, the double bonds are well-shielded and therefore hardly able to participate in a CC bond forming step. Results from the catalyst stabilization experiments are given in Table 5 . In order to determine stabilization effects on the catalyst the initial concentration of 1 was reduced to 0.15mol% and reactions conducted to final isobutene conversions. Experiments showed that the TON of the catalytic system can be increased by an equimolar addition of stilbenes, whereas the addition of tetraphenylethene leads to a decrease in the TON. The highest conversion was achieved using cis-stilbene. In comparison to trans-stilbene, a better coordination ability of cis-stilbene can be attributed to the exposed position of the double bond. Although the results with stilbenes are very promising, the decrease in TON with tetraphenylethene is hard to explain even though a hindrance caused by the fourfold coordination can be assumed. In further experiments the amount of cis-stilbene was increased to achieve an even higher TON. The highest TON was observed using a catalyst to cis-stilbene ratio of 1:4. A further increase of the cis-stilbene amount did not lead to improved catalyst stability. It is conceivable that cis-stilbene competes with isobutene regarding the coordination towards the active nickel(II) complex. Although the deactivation of the catalyst was not restrained in long-term, the increased TON demonstrates that a stabilization of the nickel catalyst is feasible with electron poor additives. 4 Conclusions We have presented a highly selective access to head-to-head co-dimers from isobutene and different 1-alkenes. Thereby, even with the highly active propene as co-substrate co-dimers were formed as main products. Further investigations on co-dimerization led to a deeper understanding regarding the pathways of insertion, wherein a distinction of the insertion steps was concluded. Additionally, an investigation on the substrate scope of 1 was performed using different vinylidene compounds. Although head-to-head homo-dimerizations of these vinylidene compounds were also feasible with very high selectivities, the catalytic system seems to be limited to aliphatic vinylidene compounds. Aromatic vinylidene compounds showed almost no reactivity with 1 but seemed to be able to prevent a decomposition of the catalyst. Subsequent investigations showed a promising strategy for the extension of the catalyst lifetime by using aromatic substituted internal alkenes as additives.
